body:
I've changed the defautls of rclone to be less verbose, like rsync.

So by default rclone won't output very much at all - only if stuff goes wrong.

With -v it will just show the transfers

With -vv it will show the full debug

Thank you didn't know that, as I typed --stats 5s as I expected the stats to show even without -v. Is it possible to have when typing --stats timer, to make the stats show even without -v. It would be a great addition.

Hey Nick, can you turn it back on with --stats (default 60s) and --stats x acting accordingly? I understand some people might not like it, but I like to see it. So can it be an option? Please? Pretty please with sugar on top?? -v is too much, and -vv is far too much. I like the updates every 60 to see what kind of bandwidth I'm getting. Maybe even just an option to do like --stats-bw that outputs total bandwidth every x seconds????? I just like to see it's doing something!

OK, using it today, I gotta say the usefulness to me without stats is severely limited. I didn't realize how much till now. I have a total per month limit, and not being able to see how much I've sent is a major issue. More or less a deal breaker (not that I have any other real choices). But I'm gonna have to go back to an older version. 

The old stats were useful, so I knew if there was a big upload it was working on before I killed it, so I didn't lose hours of upload work, but I'd live with just a total so far and average speed. Like rsync -info=progress2. I could live with that.

I get what you were trying to do, but give us options to have it the old way, or give us something better.  A display like the info=progress2 with what the threads are doing would be killer. And a -stats like rsync too, for our logs when using scripts!!!!! 

I was happy with the way it was, I get some were not I guess, but choices are always good. Why there are flags right? LOL. I love what your doing with rclone, use it every day, but I need those stats man. ;)

Please please pretty please?
@doonze I hear your impassioned plea!  I'll think about how I could make --stats appear without -v..

@ncw ok, I didn't realize -v still gave the stat window. I hadn't let it run long enough. So that's something! I can use that.... BUT!!!!! Here's something that I would like so see if you can figure out a way, you have all the info, so the only thing left is HOW. So currently we have this: 

**Transferred:**   42.317 MBytes (119.671 kBytes/s)
**Errors:**                 4
**Checks:**             28252
**Transferred:**          296
**Elapsed time:**        6m2s
**Transferring:**
 *  var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.list: 100% done, 522 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
 *  var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.postrm: 100% done, 132 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
 *  var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.md5sums: 100% done, 425 Bytes/s, ETA: 0s
 *  var/lib/dpkg/info/libssh-4:armhf.postinst:  0% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -
**Last Error:** List last error here.

I say print out this format as a static block if someone uses -stats, then update the stats in place (like --info=progress2 in rync). Adding the last error that was received at the bottom. Write off all errors to a file, then list them once the transfer is done. 

Then once the transfer is done, the last block of stats and the errors are written off to output for peoples logs that use them.

This way you can get an update on what's going on at a glance, but you don't have a scrolling wall of text both onscreen and in your logs.

Or does the new beta write a stats block when done anyway?

Ya know, something simple like that ***insert guy hiding behind the wall emoji here***

@doonze wrote
> Or does the new beta write a stats block when done anyway?

should do yes.

I like the idea about the auto updating stats block - fancy making a different issue about that?  I'll use this one to track changing --stats to show without -v if possible.
+1 for having --stats work without the -v. I like to be able to see the progress if I want to toggle it on but the -v adds too much extra info.

issue.title: Stats not showing when doing copy command

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
When filing an issue, please include the following information if possible as well as a description of the problem.  Make sure you test with the latest beta of rclone.

    http://beta.rclone.org/
    http://rclone.org/downloads/

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the [rclone forum](https://forum.rclone.org/) instead of filing an issue.

> What is your rclone version (eg output from `rclone -V`)
1.36
> Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
Ubuntu 16.10
> Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
Amazon Cloud, Google Drive
> The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
rclone copy --stats 10s "local/directory" "Amazon:/path/to/folder
> A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

issue.title: Verbose output shut off in 1.36 by default?

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Hey Nick, 

not sure if you meant to shut off the verbose output in 1.36 by any chance, seems when i run any command without -v i dont see anything when i try rclone sync, copy, move, just wanted to let you know incase you missed something before you pushed out 1.36 

Thanks 

Dedsec1

body: I'd also like to see stats work without -v.  For my use case, the only output I like to see (besides errors) is a single printing of the stats when the run finishes, summarizing the entire run, like --stats 0 used to do.  That might even be a sensible default behavior.

+1 for --stats without -v!  I think that seems cleanest to let it be mostly silent by default, yet give those of us that relied on --stats output.   I personally used it to send to a log file and then email myself status updates a few times a day.  Knowing that it was always exactly 13 lines long (with 4 transfers) let things "just work".  But -v is way too verbose and fills my log with information I don't require.    It's also helpful to be able to test a command and see it's doing what you want, and getting the speed expected by letting --stats 10s run for a while.
I throw my approval behind both --stats without -v and @doonze 's idea of stealing rsync's info=progress2.

When using rclone copy, there is no progress bar or ETA. Sometimes it looks like it is stuck.

issue.body:
There is something wrong with version 1.36

Without -v parameter it seems to not work properly. I have --stats=1s but still there is nothing in output (no syncing) Only with -v parameter it syncs like it should.
